awd_titl_txt: Anthropodynamics: Inferring the Control System Humans Use While Walking and Running
awd_abstract_narration:
Under normal circumstances, healthy adult humans can walk and run with a vanishingly small likelihood of falling. This level of assurance far exceeds the performance of state-of-the-art legged robots and robotic prosthetic devices. The goal of this project is to reverse engineer the dynamics and control of human locomotion using data from human subject experiments -- that is, to understand the control laws underlying human locomotion through observation of human subjects both walking naturally and responding to changes of terrain, sudden shoves, and other disturbances -- and to apply this understanding to more natural prosthetic devices and more capable legged robots. The results from the project will also give insight into movement disorders and other balance problems in the elderly and other at-risk populations, as well as allow design of more effective balance-improving devices.
 
In this project, the physiological control laws governing human motion will be estimated, based on experiments from both natural unperturbed walking and running, and responses to carefully chosen external perturbations during locomotion. The dynamics and the control laws near periodic motions such as walking and running will be approximated using a factorized Poincare map -- a simple generalization of the classical Poincare map. Factorized Poincare maps are inferred from experimental data using statistical techniques such as maximum likelihood estimation. The specific results this inference will allow the prediction of how the human body will return to steady locomotion in the presence of a external perturbation, in particular, it will allow the estimation of how muscle forces and body movements are modulated to recover to steady state cyclic gait. These inferred control laws will be validated using three-dimensional mathematical biped models to demonstrate quantitative prediction of movement variability and accurate estimation of the likelihood of falls.

por.por_cntn:
Healthy adult humans are capable of walking and running without falling under a variety of situations. The goal of this project was to reverse engineer the dynamics and control of human locomotion using data from human subject experiments -- that is, to understand the control laws underlying human locomotion through observation of human subjects. Towards this goal, we performed detailed experiments involving human subjects, proposed mathematical methods and models, and performed interpretable computer simulations of humans waking and running in a manner that best fit the experimental data. 

To understand how humans walk and run without falling, we collected data while humans were walking and running on a treadmill under three types of conditions: no external perturbations, with unforeseen external perturbations (pulls), and with subjects voluntarily moving away from their normal gait pattern and returning back to it. Using this extensive data set, we obtained simple yet complete models of how humans use their leg forces, foot placement, and other forces to recover from a perturbation. We then showed that these control strategies inferred from human data enable a computer model of a person (a “biped”) walk and run stably and robustly. That is, using these strategies allows the biped to walk or run without falling despite large perturbations and despite substantial uncertainty in the environment. 

Regarding the broader impacts of the project, reverse engineering the dynamics and controller for human locomotion allows us to build walking robots that walk like humans, and perhaps more significantly, prosthetic legs that behave exactly like human legs. The theory may also eventually help us better tackle falls and injury in the elderly, a concern given the country’s aging population. Our approach has produced new measures for characterizing the walking control of a person, already being used with patient populations (e.g., those with stroke). Further, the conceptual and computational tools we have created can help characterize how people may learn to use novel devices such as exoskeletons and prosthesis.

We have published the results from this project in interdisciplinary journals and presented our work at a robotics conferences, biomechanics conferences, at interdisciplinary conferences at the intersection of multiple communities, and to the general public, ensuring broad dissemination of the work and approach. The project provided the opportunity to train a PhD student at the intersection of robotics, control theory, and biomechanics. Data and computer code generated through the project is publicly shared to promote other researchers to more easily build on our work. 

 


Last Modified: 07/13/2020
Modified by: Manoj Srinivasan
